3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-analysis-idUSKBN1341L9	How Trump crushed naysayers with a coalition of the forgotten	"
By James Oliphant
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump was right. Countless others were wrong.The pundits and pollsters who said the former reality TV star could not win the U.S. presidency
column2: the Republicans who shunned him
column3: the business leaders who denounced him and the Democrats who dismissed him failed to fully understand the depth of his support. In a stunning victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton
column4: Trump stuck to a plan that worked to perfection in the Republican primary
column5: a campaign built around his blunt-talking celebrity persona
column7: and his anti-establishment message of change.""Ours was not a campaign
column8: but an incredible and great movement
column9: Trump said in his victory speech on Wednesday. It was a movement driven by discontent. The Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll found that most Americans who came to the polls were clearly angry with the direction of the country. Six out of 10 people said they felt the country is on the wrong track. Some 58 percent said ""more and more I don't identify with what America has become"" and 75 percent said ""America needs a strong leader to take the country back"" from the wealthy.Those who felt the country was on the wrong track were three times as likely to vote for Trump as Clinton. In a bitter and divisive campaign
column10: Trump cleared a series of obstacles that would doom any other candidate: An audio tape in which he talked of groping women; a refusal to release his tax returns; violence at his rallies; his mockery of a disabled  reporter; and his attacks on the heritage of a federal judge and the Muslim family of a U.S. soldier. ""He was an imperfect candidate with a near-perfect message
column12: a Republican strategist who has long backed Trump. ""I don't think a lot of people understood that.""In a year when voters in the United States and abroad showed their antipathy toward the political establishment
column15: Trump guessed correctly he could ride that wave of discontent to the White House.

column1: He exploited a growing divide in the country between whites and minorities
column2: urbanites and rural residents
column3: the college-educated and the working class. Trump beat Clinton among white men without a college degree by 31 points and white women without a degree by 27 points
column4: according to the Reuters/Ipsos polling. He also benefited from an opponent with her own flaws. Clinton was continually dragged down by questions over her use of a private email server while secretary of state and the activities of her family foundation
column5: while her corporate-friendly background left some Democrats skeptical and unenthusiastic.That appeared to cost her support among women
column6: young voters and minorities - three groups that are critical for Democrats to win big. Clinton won each of these groups
column7: but by smaller margins than President Barack Obama held when he defeated Republican candidate Mitt Romney in 2012.Some 49 percent of women supported Clinton
column8: the first woman nominee of a major party
column9: while 47 percent supported Trump. Among women between the ages of 18 and 34
column12: 62 percent of young women supported Obama

column1: THE RURAL VOTE
White voters
column2: especially men in rural areas
column3: flocked to Trump in record numbers. Trump appealed to voters unhappy with the hollowing out of the country's manufacturing sector and fearful of the country's changing demographics
column4: campaigning on a harsh anti-immigration message.  Trump won 56 percent of the white vote
column5: while Clinton won just 39 percent. He dominated to an even greater degree in rural areas
column6: where he beat Clinton by 27 points.Trump promised big things: that he would bring jobs back and punish outsourcing corporations
column7: that he would restore the country to some unspecified early time of prosperity and security - even as unemployment tumbled below 5 percent.

column1: Specifics were never Trump's strength. Instead
column2: he used an ""us versus them"" message to build voter enthusiasm in places where most Republican candidates never ventured
column3: rural areas with voters who felt ignored by Washington.Matt Borges
column4: the chairman of the Ohio Republican Party
column7: made voters feel like they mattered.Before Trump
column9: ""we weren't listening to what voters actually care about.""Trump thumbed his nose at the extensive get-out-the-vote operation and data-rich organization that are seen as essential to a modern winning campaign. His campaign relied instead on more unofficial networks of rabid supporters to get the word out. His advisers argued that he would bring scores of neglected white voters back into the political process
column10: including blue-collar Democrats in places such as Pennsylvania. Until Trump
column11: Republicans had not won Pennsylvania since 1988.Craig Robinson
column12: a veteran of Iowa Republican politics
column13: said pundits underestimated how Trump's strength in the primaries would carry over to the general election. ""In an election where the conventional wisdom was proven wrong time and time again
column14: they convinced themselves that conventional wisdom would prevail in the general election
column15: Robinson said. ""The voters saw through it.""  (Reporting by James Oliphant. Additional reporting by Chris Kahn
column16: editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Clinton'

column1: By Will Dunham
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton came closer than any other woman to winning the White House on Tuesday but fell short for a second time
column2: a bitter disappointment for a pioneering but polarizing American political figure.Seeking to win election to the office her husband Bill Clinton held from 1993 to 2001
column3: Clinton
column5: lost her battle for the Democratic presidential nomination to Barack Obama in 2008 and lost on Tuesday to Republican Donald Trump
column6: 70.Trump told supporters at a rally early on Wednesday that Clinton had phoned to congratulate him on his victory. A Clinton campaign aide confirmed the phone call.In 2000
column7: Clinton became the only first lady to win elected office
column8: as a U.S. senator from New York. In 2009
column9: she became the third female secretary of state. In July
column10: she became the first woman to claim a major U.S. party's presidential nomination. The presidency turned out to be a bridge too far.Accepting her party's nomination in July
column11: she embraced the historic nature of her candidacy
column12: saying that ""when any barrier falls in America it clears the way for everyone. After all
column14: the sky's the limit. So let's keep going. Let's keep going until every one of the 161 million women and girls across America has the opportunity she deserves to have.""    During four decades in public life
column15: Clinton withstood such controversies as an FBI investigation of her use of a private email server as secretary of state
column17: her husband's infidelity and an unsuccessful Republican effort to remove him from office.Two American women
column18: Geraldine Ferraro in 1984 and Sarah Palin in 2008
column19: were nominated by major parties as their vice presidential nominees
column20: but fell short in the general election.After losing to Obama in the 2008 race
column21: Clinton deferred her White House ambitions
column22: and served as his secretary of state from 2009 to 2013.'BETWEEN YOU AND THE APOCALYPSE'

column1: Clinton's admirers consider her a tough
column2: capable and sometimes inspirational leader who endured unrelenting efforts by political enemies to chop her down. Campaigning for her on Monday in Michigan
column3: Obama called Clinton ""a candidate who is smart
column4: a candidate who's steady
column5: a candidate who's tested - probably the most qualified person ever to run for this office.""Her detractors consider her an unscrupulous and power-hungry opportunist. She was detested by many Republicans and conservatives
column6: and in 1998 during her husband's presidency bemoaned a ""vast right-wing conspiracy.""Against Trump
column7: she portrayed herself as guarding the country from the threat she said he posed to American democracy.""As I've told people
column8: I'm the last thing standing between you and the apocalypse
column9: Clinton told The New York Times in October.When she entered the race last year for the Democratic presidential nomination
column10: she was considered such a prohibitive favorite that others in her party shied away from challenging her. But she was an establishment figure and a Washington insider at a time when voters were smitten with outsiders.She secured the Democratic nomination in July only after beating back a surprisingly stout challenge from U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders
column11: who appealed to young voters and mustered the kind of excitement that Clinton sometimes failed to generate.

column1: As secretary of state
column2: she dealt with civil wars in Syria and Libya
column3: Iran's nuclear program
column4: China's growing clout
column8: and an unsuccessful bid to settle the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.EMAIL CONTROVERSY

column1: Congressional Republicans spent years investigating allegations of State Department security lapses related to a 2012 attack by militants in the Libyan city of Benghazi that killed the U.S. ambassador.She testified during marathon congressional hearings in January 2013 at the end of her tenure at the State Department and in October 2015
column2: while already a candidate for president
column3: facing Republican criticism of her handling of the incident.Another politically damaging issue came to light during the lengthy congressional investigation into the Benghazi attack: accusations that she broke the law in her handling of classified information while corresponding through the private email server for her government work as secretary of state.The U.S. Justice Department in July accepted FBI Director James Comey's recommendation not to bring criminal charges against her
column4: although he faulted her ""extremely careless""  handling of classified information.Comey announced 11 days before the election that the FBI was investigating a new collection of emails as part of its probe
column5: but said two days before the election that a review of those emails produced nothing that would change the decision not to bring charges.Trump called her ""Crooked Hillary
column6: said he would seek to put her behind bars if elected and encouraged his supporters to chant ""lock her up."" Clinton called Trump as a racist hate-monger
column7: a sexist and a tax-dodger enamored with Russian President Vladimir Putin. She defended her lengthy service in government
column8: dismissing Trump's contention that she had produced no real accomplishments.

column1: CONSERVATIVE UPBRINGING
Born in Chicago on Oct. 26
column3: Hillary Rodham Clinton was  the eldest of three children of a small-business owner father she called a ""rock-ribbed
column4: up-by-your-bootstraps
column5: conservative Republican"" and a mother who was a closet Democrat.She attended public schools
column6: then enrolled in 1965 at all-female Wellesley College in Massachusetts
column7: where she headed the Young Republicans Club. Her political views changed during the 1960s civil rights struggles and Vietnam War escalation and she switched parties.At Yale Law School
column8: she met a similarly ambitious fellow student from Arkansas
column10: and they became a couple. She moved to Washington to work for a congressional panel in the impeachment drive against Nixon
column11: who resigned as president in 1974 during the Watergate scandal.She moved to Arkansas to be with Bill
column13: and was hired by a top law firm. He jumped into politics
column16: in 1978. She gave birth to the couple's only child
column19: she was a high-powered lawyer in the capital Little Rock and a Wal-Mart corporate board member.Most Americans were introduced to her during her husband's bid for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. Bill Clinton said voters would get ""two for the price of one"" if they elected him. She unapologetically said she was not a woman who ""stayed home and baked cookies.""

column1: After a woman named Gennifer Flowers accused Bill Clinton during the campaign of a sexual affair
column2: Hillary Clinton appeared on TV with her husband and referred to singer Tammy Wynette's song
column3: ""Stand by Your Man.""""You know
column4: I'm not sitting here
column5: some little woman standing by my man like Tammy Wynette
column7: adding that she loved and respected her husband. ""And you know
column8: if that's not enough for people
column11: she added. Conservative critics painted her as a radical feminist and a threat to traditional family values.Bill Clinton defeated incumbent Republican President George H.W. Bush in November 1992. As first lady from 1993 to 2001
column13: she was an active part of policymaking.'HILLARYCARE'

column1: Critics assailed her unsuccessful effort to win congressional passage of healthcare reform
column2: deriding it as ""Hillarycare.""She and her husband faced a long investigation into past business dealings but ultimately no criminal charges were brought. A real estate venture known as Whitewater faced scrutiny
column3: spawning an independent counsel investigation that later encompassed Bill Clinton's sexual relationship with a White House intern named Monica Lewinsky.Deputy White House Counsel Vince Foster
column4: a figure in the Whitewater controversy and a close friend of the Clintons from Arkansas
column5: was found dead of a gunshot in 1993. His death was ruled a suicide. In a 2003 memoir
column6: Hillary Clinton blasted ""conspiracy theorists and investigators trying to prove that Vince was murdered to cover up what he 'knew about Whitewater.'"" In 2000
column7: the independent counsel investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence to show the Clintons had been involved in any criminal behavior related to Whitewater.In December 1998
column8: the Republican-led House of Representatives voted to impeach a president for only the second time in U.S. history
column9: charging Bill Clinton with ""high crimes and misdemeanors"" for allegedly lying under oath and obstructing justice to cover up his relationship with Lewinsky.The Republican-led Senate acquitted Clinton in February 1999. Hillary Clinton called the impeachment an abuse of power by Republicans with a ""Soviet-style show trial"" and condemned what she called ""an attempted congressional coup d'etat.""She also said she ""wanted to wring Bill's neck"" for the affair and upbraided him privately. Ultimately
column11: she decided she still loved him and remained after they went through counseling.She launched her own bid for elected office and won election in 2000 as a U.S. senator.The 2008 race for the Democratic presidential nomination pitted America's foremost woman politician against the son of a black Kenyan father and a white Kansan mother. After vanquishing Clinton
column12: Obama made history when he defeated Republican John McCain to become the first black U.S. president. (Writing and reporting by Will Dunham in Washington; Editing by Howard Goller)"	['Obama'
